mnemonic: DEXTERity → DEXTER means 'right-handed' (traditionally the skillful hand) → skill with the hands or mind.

core_meaning: to drink (alcohol); to absorb or assimilate (ideas or knowledge)
figurative_meaning: to take in mentally
etymology_root: From Latin imbibere, from in- 'in' + bibere 'to drink'.

by_level.simple: It is illegal to imbibe alcohol under the age of 18.
by_level.intermediate: She imbibed the culture of the country during her year abroad.
by_level.advanced: The students were encouraged to imbibe the principles of critical thinking.

formal: He had a tendency to imbibe to excess.
Young minds readily imbibe new information.
informal: They went to the pub to imbibe a few pints.
You can really imbibe the local vibe at that café.
technical: In biology, a seed imbibes water to begin germination.
The study examined how children imbibe social norms from their environment.
literary: He imbibed the wisdom of the ancient texts.
She stood on the cliff, imbibing the grandeur of the ocean.

tone: formal, literary, sometimes humorous for alcohol
grammar_usage_notes: Formal for 'drink', especially alcohol. Figurative use is common.
exceptions_restrictions: Formal or humorous when referring to alcohol.
mnemonic: IMBIBE → to take IN (im-) a drink (BIBE) → to drink or absorb.

core_meaning: patient self-control; restraint and tolerance; the action of refraining from exercising a legal right
figurative_meaning: clemency or leniency
etymology_root: From Old French forberance, from forber 'to forbear'.

by_level.simple: She listened to his complaints with great forbearance.
by_level.intermediate: The bank agreed to a period of forbearance on the loan.
by_level.advanced: His forbearance in the face of extreme provocation was remarkable.

formal: The judge urged forbearance in the application of the strict letter of the law.
The creditor granted a temporary forbearance on the debt payments.
informal: You need to have a lot of forbearance to deal with young children.
I'm asking for your forbearance while we get this sorted out.
technical: In finance, forbearance is a temporary postponement of loan payments.
In law, forbearance can be a form of consideration in a contract.
literary: He practiced a stoic forbearance, enduring his hardships without complaint.
Her forbearance was a testament to her strength of character.

grammar_usage_notes: Uncountable noun. A formal word for patience.
exceptions_restrictions: Formal word; also a specific financial/legal term.
mnemonic: FORBEARance → to BEAR with someone → patient self-control.

core_meaning: to make great efforts to achieve or obtain something
figurative_meaning: to endeavor earnestly
etymology_root: From Old French estriver, from estrif 'strife'.

by_level.simple: We must strive to do better.
by_level.intermediate: The company strives for excellence in customer service.
by_level.advanced: Throughout his career, he strove to bridge the gap between theory and practice.

formal: The nation strives towards a more equitable society.
We shall continue to strive for a peaceful resolution.
informal: Just strive to be a better person every day.
I'm striving to get a promotion this year.
technical: In optimization algorithms, the system strives to find a global minimum.
The organization's mission is to strive for sustainable development.
literary: He strove against the currents of fate.
She strove with all her might to reach the summit.

grammar_usage_notes: Irregular verb: strive, strove, striven. Often used with 'for' or 'to'.
exceptions_restrictions: Implies sustained and vigorous effort.
mnemonic: STRIVE → sounds like 'STRIVE to SURVIVE' → to make great efforts.

core_meaning: to apply or bring to bear (a force, influence, or quality); to make a physical or mental effort
literal_meaning: to put forth strength or effort
figurative_meaning: to bring into operation
etymology_root: From Latin exserere 'put forth', from ex- 'out' + serere 'bind, join'.

by_level.simple: You need to exert more pressure to open the jar.
by_level.intermediate: The company exerted its influence to change the law.
by_level.advanced: He had to exert all his willpower to remain calm.

formal: The gas exerts a pressure on the container walls.
The group exerts considerable control over the market.
informal: Don't exert yourself; I can carry the bags.
She's exerting a lot of effort to finish on time.
technical: In physics, a force is exerted when one object acts upon another.
The study examined how peer groups exert social pressure on individuals.
literary: He exerted his authority with a quiet word.
A calming influence was exerted by her mere presence.

grammar_usage_notes: Often used with 'oneself' (exert oneself) to mean 'make a physical effort'.
exceptions_restrictions: Can be used for both physical force and abstract influence.
mnemonic: EXERT → to put forth EFFORT or FORCE.

core_meaning: the comfort received by a person after a loss or disappointment; a source of such comfort
literal_meaning: something that makes you feel less sad
figurative_meaning: a small compensation in the face of a larger loss
etymology_root: From Latin consolatio(n-), from consolari 'to console'.

by_level.simple: It was a consolation to know she wasn't badly hurt.
by_level.intermediate: He found consolation in his music after his friend moved away.
by_level.advanced: The fact that we played well was cold consolation for the defeat.

formal: The letter offered little consolation to the grieving family.
He derived some consolation from his religious faith.
informal: If you don't win, at least you get a consolation prize.
Well, the consolation is that we don't have to get up early tomorrow.
technical: In philosophy, the 'consolations of philosophy' is a concept tracing back to Boethius.
The theory explores art as a form of existential consolation.
literary: Her presence was his only consolation in a world grown dark.
The quiet beauty of the evening was a gentle consolation.

grammar_usage_notes: Often used in the phrase 'consolation prize' for a prize given to a runner-up.
exceptions_restrictions: Often implies that the comfort does not fully make up for the loss.
mnemonic: CONSOLation → it CONSOLes you → provides comfort.

core_meaning: a legacy, something that is handed down or given to someone in a will
figurative_meaning: something passed on from a previous generation
etymology_root: From Old English becwiss, from becwethan 'bequeath'.

by_level.simple: She left a bequest to the local animal shelter in her will.
by_level.intermediate: The library was built with a bequest from a wealthy industrialist.
by_level.advanced: The cultural bequest of the ancient civilization continues to influence modern art.

formal: The museum benefited from a substantial bequest of 19th-century paintings.
The terms of the bequest stipulated that the money be used for educational purposes.
informal: My grandfather's bequest allowed me to buy my first house.
He got a nice bequest from a distant relative.
technical: In law, a bequest is a gift of personal property, while a devise is a gift of real property.
The bequest was subject to inheritance tax.
literary: The greatest bequest his father gave him was not wealth, but integrity.
We are the guardians of a precious bequest from the past.

grammar_usage_notes: A formal word for something left in a will.
exceptions_restrictions: Specifically refers to property or money given through a will.
mnemonic: BEQUEST → you REQUEST it to be given after you're gone → a legacy in a will.

core_meaning: an area of low-lying, uncultivated ground where water collects; to overwhelm or flood with too much of something
figurative_meaning: to inundate or overload
etymology_root: Probably from a Germanic word meaning 'sponge' or 'fungus'.

by_level.simple: Alligators live in the swamp.
by_level.intermediate: After the announcement, the office was swamped with phone calls.
by_level.advanced: The small legal aid service was swamped by the sheer volume of cases.

formal: The coastal plain is characterized by extensive swamps and marshes.
The department was swamped by the administrative burden.
informal: I can't go out; I'm completely swamped.
Don't swamp the boat!
technical: In ecology, a swamp is a forested wetland.
The server was swamped with requests, causing it to crash.
literary: A feeling of despair swamped her.
The old road was slowly being reclaimed by the swamp.

tone: negative when used as a verb (overwhelmed), neutral as a noun (geographical)
grammar_usage_notes: As a verb, often used in the passive voice (be swamped with).
exceptions_restrictions: Figurative use is very common in informal and business contexts.
mnemonic: SWAMP → a WET area that can overWHELM you if you're not careful → to overwhelm.

core_meaning: to enjoy or take pleasure in something; great enjoyment; a spicy condiment
figurative_meaning: to anticipate with pleasure
etymology_root: From Old French reles 'remainder', from relaisser 'to release'. The verb sense developed from the idea of 'flavour' or 'aftertaste'.

by_level.simple: I don't relish the thought of cleaning my room.
by_level.intermediate: She relished the chance to travel.
by_level.advanced: He relished the intellectual duel with his sharp-witted opponent.

formal: The general relished the prospect of a decisive battle.
He told the story with obvious relish.
informal: I relish a good mystery novel.
He ate his hot dog with plenty of relish.
literary: She relished the solitude of the early morning.
A cruel smile played on his lips, as if he relished their discomfort.

grammar_usage_notes: As a verb, it is followed by a noun or gerund (relish doing something).
exceptions_restrictions: Can sometimes imply enjoying something others might not (e.g., a challenge, a fight).
mnemonic: RELISH the food → enjoy it greatly.

core_meaning: to transfer or delegate (power, authority, or responsibility) to a lower level; to degenerate or deteriorate
figurative_meaning: to fall into a worse state
etymology_root: From Latin devolvere 'roll down', from de- 'down' + volvere 'to roll'.

by_level.simple: The meeting devolved into an argument.
by_level.intermediate: The central government devolved some powers to the regional assemblies.
by_level.advanced: In the absence of the manager, responsibility devolves upon the deputy.

formal: The constitution devolves certain legislative powers to the states.
The debate devolved into a series of personal attacks.
informal: Their conversation quickly devolved into gossip.
The party devolved into a mess after midnight.
technical: In biology, a trait is said to devolve when it reverts to a simpler or more primitive form.
In political science, devolution is the statutory delegation of powers from a central government to a regional one.
literary: The kingdom devolved into anarchy after the king's death.
The duty devolved to him as the eldest son.

tone: political, formal for transfer; negative for deteriorate
grammar_usage_notes: Often used with 'into' (devolve into chaos) or 'to/upon' (devolve to a person/body).
exceptions_restrictions: Has two distinct meanings: a neutral/political one (transfer power) and a negative one (deteriorate).
mnemonic: DEVOLVE → to pass DOWN (de-) → to transfer power down, or to go down in quality.

core_meaning: the action of providing or supplying something; a condition or requirement in a legal document; supplies of food, drink, or equipment
figurative_meaning: a preparatory measure
etymology_root: From Latin provision(n-), from providere 'foresee, attend to' (from pro- 'before' + videre 'to see').

by_level.simple: We need to buy provisions for the camping trip.
by_level.intermediate: The contract includes a provision for early termination.
by_level.advanced: The government is responsible for the provision of essential services.

formal: The act contains a provision that safeguards the rights of minorities.
Adequate provision must be made for future contingencies.
informal: We've got enough provisions to last the weekend.
There's a provision in my lease about pets.
technical: In accounting, a provision is a liability of uncertain timing or amount.
In contract law, a severability provision allows the rest of a contract to stand if one part is invalid.
literary: They made their way west with only meager provisions.
He had made no provision for his old age.

grammar_usage_notes: Used in many contexts: legal (clause), logistical (supplies), and general (the act of providing).
exceptions_restrictions: A very common and versatile word.
mnemonic: PROVISION → the act of PROVIding → supplying something or a condition for supply.

core_meaning: to leave (property, money, etc.) to a person or other beneficiary by a will; to pass (something) on or leave to a successor
figurative_meaning: to hand down
etymology_root: From Old English becwethan, from be- 'about' + cwethan 'say'.

by_level.simple: She bequeathed her entire estate to her daughter.
by_level.intermediate: The previous manager bequeathed a number of unresolved problems.
by_level.advanced: The ancient civilization bequeathed to us a rich cultural heritage.

formal: He bequeathed his art collection to the national gallery.
The founding fathers bequeathed a system of government based on checks and balances.
informal: My aunt bequeathed me her pearl necklace.
He was bequeathed a large sum of money.
technical: In legal terms, to bequeath is to give personal property, while to devise is to give real property.
The testator bequeathed the residue of the estate to charity.
literary: He bequeathed to his son a name that was synonymous with honor.
The old sage bequeathed his wisdom to the young apprentice.

grammar_usage_notes: A formal word. Often used in the passive voice in legal contexts.
exceptions_restrictions: The verb form of 'bequest'.
mnemonic: BEQUEATH → you state in your will who will be your heir → to leave something in a will.

core_meaning: (adj.) having or showing the ability to speak fluently and coherently; (verb.) to express (an idea or feeling) fluently and coherently
figurative_meaning: to form a joint or connection
etymology_root: From Latin articulatus, from articulus 'small connecting part', from artus 'joint'.

by_level.simple: She is very articulate and explains things well.
by_level.intermediate: He found it difficult to articulate his feelings.
by_level.advanced: The theory articulates a new framework for understanding economic behavior.

formal: The ambassador was articulate in her defense of the policy.
The document articulates the core principles of the organization.
informal: You need to be more articulate if you want people to understand you.
I can't quite articulate why I feel this way.
technical: In anatomy, bones articulate at the joints.
In linguistics, we articulate sounds using our vocal apparatus.
literary: He was a man of few but perfectly articulated words.
A hope she could not articulate stirred within her.

grammar_usage_notes: As an adjective, it describes a person or their speech. As a verb, it is transitive.
exceptions_restrictions: A highly positive trait when describing someone's communication skills.
mnemonic: ARTICULATE → think of the joints (ARTICulations) in a skeleton that allow clear movement → to express ideas clearly.

core_meaning: each of two parts into which a thing is or can be divided; a part or portion, especially a lesser share
figurative_meaning: a distinct part of something
etymology_root: From Old French moite, from Latin medietas 'middle', from medius 'mid, middle'.

by_level.simple: The inheritance was split into two moieties.
by_level.intermediate: A significant moiety of the budget was allocated to research.
by_level.advanced: In some kinship systems, a society is divided into two moieties for marriage purposes.

formal: The testator left a moiety of his residual estate to each of his two children.
The molecule consists of two distinct moieties.
technical: In chemistry, a moiety is a specific segment of a molecule.
In anthropology, a moiety is one of two basic tribal subdivisions.
literary: He bequeathed a moiety of his heart to his country, and the other to his beloved.
The sun had passed the moiety of its daily course.

grammar_usage_notes: A formal and somewhat rare word, mostly used in legal, scientific, and anthropological contexts.
exceptions_restrictions: Very formal; not used in everyday conversation.
mnemonic: MOIETY → sounds like 'MY half-ITY' → one of two parts, a half.

core_meaning: preservation or deliverance from harm, ruin, or loss; in theology, deliverance from sin and its consequences
figurative_meaning: a source or means of being saved
etymology_root: From Old French salvaciun, from ecclesiastical Latin salvatio(n-), from salvare 'to save'.

by_level.simple: The arrival of the rescue team was our salvation.
by_level.intermediate: She found salvation in her faith during a difficult time.
by_level.advanced: The loan was the salvation of the company, preventing its immediate collapse.

formal: The doctrine of salvation is central to Christian theology.
They saw education as the salvation of the poorer classes.
informal: That cup of coffee was my salvation this morning.
I can't find my keys—you're my salvation!
technical: In theology, soteriology is the study of salvation.
The concept of political salvation has been used by various ideologies.
literary: He sought salvation in the wilderness, far from the corruption of the city.
Her love was his salvation from a life of despair.

grammar_usage_notes: Often used with 'find' or 'seek'. Can be used in both religious and secular contexts.
exceptions_restrictions: Capital 'S' Salvation often refers to the Christian concept.
mnemonic: SALVation → related to SAVE → deliverance from harm.

core_meaning: to put off (an action or event) to a later time; to yield to another's judgment or opinion
figurative_meaning: to show respect
etymology_root: From Latin differre 'carry apart, delay, differ', from dis- 'apart' + ferre 'to carry'.

by_level.simple: He deferred his vacation until the summer.
by_level.intermediate: I will defer to your greater experience in this matter.
by_level.advanced: The court deferred judgment pending further evidence.

formal: The committee voted to defer consideration of the motion.
In matters of theology, he deferred to the bishop.
informal: Let's defer that discussion until tomorrow.
Okay, I defer to you on this one.
technical: In finance, deferred tax is a liability on a balance sheet.
Many universities offer deferred admission programs.
literary: He deferred to her wisdom in all things.
The moment of reckoning could be deferred, but not avoided.

grammar_usage_notes: The meaning changes based on the preposition: 'defer something' (postpone) vs. 'defer to someone' (yield).
exceptions_restrictions: Two distinct meanings: delay and yield.
mnemonic: DEFER → to put OFF until later, or to give OFf your opinion to someone else.

core_meaning: optimistic or positive, especially in a difficult situation; (archaic) blood-red
figurative_meaning: hopeful about the future
etymology_root: From Old French sanguin(e) 'blood red', from Latin sanguineus, from sanguis, sanguin- 'blood'. In medieval physiology, a sanguine temperament was associated with blood and characterized by courage, hope, and a ruddy complexion.

by_level.simple: He is sanguine about his chances of winning.
by_level.intermediate: Despite the setbacks, she remained sanguine.
by_level.advanced: The CEO struck a sanguine note in her address to the shareholders, predicting strong growth.

formal: Analysts are less sanguine about the company's prospects than its management.
He maintained a sanguine disposition throughout the crisis.
informal: I'm feeling pretty sanguine about the interview.
You're very sanguine for someone who just lost their job.
technical: In the context of the four humors, a sanguine personality is sociable and outgoing.
The forecast was revised based on less sanguine economic indicators.
literary: His sanguine hopes were dashed by the cold reality.
She painted a sanguine picture of their future together.

grammar_usage_notes: Often used with 'about'. A formal word for optimism.
exceptions_restrictions: Formal tone; not to be confused with 'sanguinary' which means 'bloody'.
mnemonic: SANGUINE → related to SANG (blood) → in old times, a healthy blood count meant a cheerful, optimistic temperament.

core_meaning: to grow or develop well or vigorously; to prosper or flourish
figurative_meaning: to be successful
etymology_root: From Old Norse thrífask, reflexive of thrífa 'to grasp'.

by_level.simple: Plants thrive in sunlight.
by_level.intermediate: Some people thrive under pressure.
by_level.advanced: The arts thrived during the reign of the enlightened monarch.

formal: The company continues to thrive in a competitive market.
Children thrive in a stable and nurturing environment.
informal: My cactus is finally thriving!
He's not just surviving in his new job; he's thriving.
technical: In ecology, a species thrives when it finds its optimal niche.
The start-up thrived due to its innovative business model.
literary: Love thrives not in the heart that is filled with hate.
The village thrived, its fields abundant and its people content.

grammar_usage_notes: Irregular verb: thrive, thrived (or throve), thrived (or thriven). Often used with 'on' (thrive on pressure).
exceptions_restrictions: Implies not just success, but vigorous growth and health.
mnemonic: THRIVE → to be full of life and grow STRONGly.

core_meaning: delaying or delayed beyond the right or expected time; slow
figurative_meaning: slow to act or respond
etymology_root: From Latin tardus 'slow'.

by_level.simple: She was tardy for school three times this week.
by_level.intermediate: The company was tardy in issuing a public apology.
by_level.advanced: Justice, though tardy, finally prevailed.

formal: We apologize for our tardy reply to your letter.
The government's response to the crisis was widely criticized as tardy.
informal: Don't be tardy for the movie!
He's always so tardy.
technical: In education, chronic tardiness can be a sign of underlying issues.
A tardy pulse is a slow heart rate.
literary: Spring was tardy that year, the snow lingering on the hills.
He offered a tardy recognition of her merits.

grammar_usage_notes: A formal word for 'late', often used in educational or official contexts.
exceptions_restrictions: More formal than 'late'; often used for people's arrival or responses.
mnemonic: TARDY → sounds like 'RETARDed' which means delayed or slow → late.

core_meaning: a person who carries out a harmful, illegal, or immoral act
figurative_meaning: the one responsible for a negative action
etymology_root: From Latin perpetrat- 'performed', from the verb perpetrare, from per- 'to completion' + patrare 'bring about'.

by_level.simple: The police are searching for the perpetrator.
by_level.intermediate: The perpetrators of the fraud were sentenced to prison.
by_level.advanced: The regime was the main perpetrator of human rights abuses in the region.

formal: The identity of the perpetrator remains unknown.
We must hold the perpetrators of these atrocities accountable.
informal: They caught the perpetrator red-handed.
Who was the perpetrator of this mess?
technical: In criminology, perpetrator profiling is used to narrow down suspects.
The study focused on the socio-economic background of the perpetrators.
literary: He was the silent perpetrator of her misery.
The true perpetrator of the plot was never discovered.

grammar_usage_notes: Used for the person who commits a crime or bad act.
exceptions_restrictions: Strongly associated with crime and wrongdoing.
mnemonic: PERPETRATOR → the one who PERPETRATES a crime → the person who commits it.

core_meaning: to restore friendly relations between; to cause to coexist in harmony; to make one account consistent with another
figurative_meaning: to accept something unpleasant
etymology_root: From Latin reconciliare, from re- 'back' + conciliare 'bring together'.

by_level.simple: I reconciled with my friend after our argument.
by_level.intermediate: It's hard to reconcile his friendly words with his aggressive actions.
by_level.advanced: The couple sought counseling to reconcile their conflicting life goals.

formal: The two nations were reconciled after decades of hostility.
The accountant worked to reconcile the discrepancies in the ledger.
informal: Have you reconciled with your brother yet?
I can't reconcile myself to the idea of moving.
technical: In accounting, bank reconciliation is the process of matching balances.
In theology, reconciliation refers to the end of estrangement between God and humanity.
literary: He could never reconcile the two warring halves of his nature.
She was reconciled to her fate.

grammar_usage_notes: Often used with 'with' (reconcile with someone) or 'to' (reconcile oneself to something).
exceptions_restrictions: Used in personal, financial, and ideological contexts.
mnemonic: RECONCILE → to bring back together (re-) and make things peaceful (conciliatory).

core_meaning: acting with or showing care and thought for the future
figurative_meaning: circumspect and discreet
etymology_root: From Old French prudent, from Latin prudent- 'foreseeing, wise', contraction of providens, from providere 'foresee, attend to'.

by_level.simple: It would be prudent to save some money for emergencies.
by_level.intermediate: The minister made a prudent decision to delay the announcement.
by_level.advanced: A prudent investor diversifies their portfolio to manage risk.

formal: The committee exercised prudent judgment in its recommendations.
Prudent fiscal management is essential for economic stability.
informal: It's just not prudent to drive in this storm.
He's very prudent with his money.
technical: In law, the 'prudent man rule' is a guideline for fiduciary responsibility.
The principle of prudent avoidance is used in environmental policy.
literary: She was a woman of prudent and temperate habits.
His prudent counsel often saved the kingdom from disaster.

grammar_usage_notes: A positive adjective describing careful and sensible behavior.
exceptions_restrictions: Often used in financial and decision-making contexts.
mnemonic: PRUDENT → sounds like 'PROVIDENT' which means careful for the future → wise and careful.

core_meaning: in a very unhappy or unfortunate state; of poor quality; despicable
figurative_meaning: thoroughly miserable
etymology_root: From Old English wrecca 'wretch, stranger, outlaw'.

by_level.simple: The refugees were living in wretched poverty.
by_level.intermediate: I had a wretched headache all day.
by_level.advanced: He was a wretched coward who betrayed his friends.

formal: The prisoners were kept in wretched conditions.
She made a wretched attempt to explain herself.
informal: I feel absolutely wretched with this cold.
What wretched weather for a picnic!
literary: The wretched soul wandered the earth, seeking peace.
A wretched hovel was their only shelter from the storm.

grammar_usage_notes: Can describe both a state (feeling wretched) and a person's character (a wretched liar).
exceptions_restrictions: A strong word for extreme unhappiness or poor quality.
mnemonic: WRETCHed → a miserable WRETCH → very unhappy or of poor quality.

core_meaning: an idea or feeling that a word invokes in addition to its literal or primary meaning
literal_meaning: the implied meaning of a word
figurative_meaning: the emotional or cultural association
etymology_root: From medieval Latin connotatio(n-), from connotare 'mark in addition', from con- 'together with' + notare 'to note'.

by_level.simple: The word 'childish' has a negative connotation.
by_level.intermediate: The word 'home' has connotations of warmth and safety.
by_level.advanced: The political speech was carefully crafted to avoid any negative connotations.

formal: The term carries a pejorative connotation in academic discourse.
We must consider the cultural connotations of this symbol.
informal: That word has a bad connotation.
What are the connotations of calling someone 'cheap' vs. 'frugal'?
technical: In semiotics, connotation is the secondary meaning derived from cultural context.
Linguists study the connotative meaning of words as opposed to their denotative meaning.
literary: The name held dark connotations of a forgotten tragedy.
The color white has different connotations in Eastern and Western cultures.

grammar_usage_notes: Contrasted with 'denotation', which is the literal meaning.
exceptions_restrictions: A key concept in linguistics and literary analysis.
mnemonic: CONNOTATION → the meaning that comes WITH (con-) the word → the implied feeling.

core_meaning: unfriendly, unsympathetic, or hostile
figurative_meaning: having an unfavorable opinion
etymology_root: From ill + disposed.

by_level.simple: She was ill-disposed towards the new plan.
by_level.intermediate: The manager was ill-disposed to grant any more requests.
by_level.advanced: The critic was fundamentally ill-disposed towards the entire genre of romantic comedy.

formal: The committee was ill-disposed to approve the controversial proposal.
He was ill-disposed towards his rival's success.
informal: I'm feeling a bit ill-disposed towards him after what he said.
Why are you so ill-disposed?
literary: Fortune, ever ill-disposed towards him, dealt another blow.
The gods seemed ill-disposed to grant their prayers.

grammar_usage_notes: Always used with 'towards' or 'to' (ill-disposed towards someone/something).
exceptions_restrictions: A formal way to say 'unfriendly' or 'opposed'.
mnemonic: ILL-DISPOSED → having a bad (ILL) disposition (mood/attitude) → unfriendly or hostile.

core_meaning: conformity to conventionally accepted standards of behavior or morals; the state or quality of being correct or appropriate
figurative_meaning: socially correct behavior
etymology_root: From late Middle English (in the sense 'peculiarity, essential quality'): from Old French propriete, from Latin proprietas 'ownership, property', from proprius 'one's own, particular'.

by_level.simple: She always acts with perfect propriety.
by_level.intermediate: Some questioned the propriety of the minister's business dealings.
by_level.advanced: The board reviewed the contract for legal and ethical propriety.

formal: He conducted himself with the utmost propriety throughout the proceedings.
There are serious questions regarding the propriety of this arrangement.
informal: My grandmother is very strict about propriety.
I'm not sure about the propriety of discussing this here.
technical: In diplomatic circles, strict rules of propriety govern official conduct.
The audit examined the financial propriety of the transactions.
literary: She was a model of Victorian propriety, never putting a foot wrong.
He cast aside all notions of propriety in his pursuit of the truth.

grammar_usage_notes: Uncountable noun. Often used in formal or social contexts.
exceptions_restrictions: Often implies a somewhat rigid adherence to social conventions.
mnemonic: PROPRIETY → following what is PROPER → correct behavior.

core_meaning: to suffer (something painful or difficult) patiently; to remain in existence; to last
figurative_meaning: to withstand the test of time
etymology_root: From Old French endurer, from Latin indurare 'harden', from in- 'in' + durus 'hard'.

by_level.simple: She had to endure a long and painful recovery.
by_level.intermediate: Their friendship has endured for over fifty years.
by_level.advanced: The ancient ruins have endured millennia of weathering and conflict.

formal: The soldiers endured unimaginable conditions during the siege.
Few relationships can endure such fundamental disagreements.
informal: I can't endure this noise any longer!
How do you endure your boss?
technical: The material is engineered to endure extreme temperatures.
In psychology, the capacity to endure stress is a key aspect of resilience.
literary: Love endures all things, believes all things, hopes all things.
He endured his suffering in silence, a stoic to the end.

grammar_usage_notes: Can be used both transitively (endure pain) and intransitively (a legacy that endures).
exceptions_restrictions: Often implies patience and strength in the face of difficulty.
mnemonic: ENDURE → to be DURable and last, or to bear something difficult.

core_meaning: to feel or express sincere regret or remorse about one's wrongdoing or sin
literal_meaning: to feel sorry for past actions
figurative_meaning: to change one's mind
etymology_root: From Old French repentir, based on Latin paenitere 'cause to repent'.

by_level.simple: He repented of his unkind words.
by_level.intermediate: The criminal showed no sign of repenting.
by_level.advanced: She repented at leisure the hasty decision she had made in haste.

formal: The preacher called on the congregation to repent their transgressions.
He died repentant, seeking forgiveness for his life of crime.
informal: You'll repent this later!
I repent ever getting involved in this scheme.
technical: In theology, repentance involves both contrition (sorrow for sin) and a firm purpose of amendment.
The concept of repenting is central to many religious traditions.
literary: "Repent, for the kingdom of heaven is at hand!"
He repented in dust and ashes.

grammar_usage_notes: Often used with 'of' (repent of something). Stronger than 'regret'; implies a moral or spiritual dimension.
exceptions_restrictions: Often has a religious connotation.
mnemonic: REPENT → you feel so sorry you'd do it again if you could, but you PENitently can't.

core_meaning: the quality of being unwise or lacking discretion; a rash or ill-advised act
figurative_meaning: foolhardiness
etymology_root: From French imprudence, from Latin imprudentia, from in- 'not' + prudentia 'foresight, wisdom'.

by_level.simple: It was an act of great imprudence to go out in the storm.
by_level.intermediate: His financial imprudence left him in debt.
by_level.advanced: The diplomat's imprudence nearly caused an international incident.

formal: The company's failure was a direct result of managerial imprudence.
She later regretted the imprudence of her confession.
informal: That was sheer imprudence!
I admit it was an imprudence, but I meant well.
technical: In law, contributory negligence may arise from a plaintiff's imprudence.
The economic crisis was exacerbated by fiscal imprudence.
literary: The follies and imprudences of his youth haunted him.
A moment's imprudence can cost a lifetime of regret.

grammar_usage_notes: The noun form of 'imprudent'. A formal word for foolishness.
exceptions_restrictions: More formal than 'foolishness' or 'carelessness'.
mnemonic: IMprudence → NOT prudent → unwise and careless.

core_meaning: having or displaying a friendly and pleasant manner
figurative_meaning: characterized by friendliness
etymology_root: From Old French amiable, from late Latin amicabilis 'friendly', from Latin amicus 'friend'.

by_level.simple: Our new neighbors are very amiable.
by_level.intermediate: They had an amiable discussion over coffee.
by_level.advanced: Despite their political differences, they maintained an amiable correspondence.

formal: The negotiations were conducted in an amiable atmosphere.
He was an amiable host, putting all his guests at ease.
informal: He's a really amiable guy.
We had an amiable chat.
literary: She had an amiable face, quick to smile.
The amiable old gentleman was a favorite in the village.

grammar_usage_notes: Describes a person's character or the nature of a relationship or atmosphere.
exceptions_restrictions: A positive and somewhat formal word for friendliness.
mnemonic: AMIABLE → sounds like 'a mi-ABLE' person → friendly and pleasant.

core_meaning: a picture, description, or imitation of a person in which certain striking characteristics are exaggerated in order to create a comic or grotesque effect; to make or give a caricature of
figurative_meaning: a distorted representation
etymology_root: From Italian caricatura, from caricare 'load, exaggerate', from Latin carricare.

by_level.simple: The artist drew a funny caricature of the mayor.
by_level.intermediate: His performance was a caricature of a mad scientist.
by_level.advanced: The novel presents a caricature of bourgeois society, exaggerating its hypocrisies for satirical effect.

formal: The article presented a caricature of the opposing viewpoint.
He was a master of the political caricature.
informal: That's not a portrait; it's a caricature!
He does great caricatures of famous people.
technical: In art, caricature relies on the exaggeration of physiognomic features.
In rhetoric, a straw man argument often involves creating a caricature of an opponent's position.
literary: He had become a caricature of his former self.
Her memory of him was a caricature, all his faults magnified and his virtues forgotten.

grammar_usage_notes: Often implies a simplification and exaggeration for comic or critical effect.
exceptions_restrictions: Can be negative when it implies a unfair or overly simplistic representation.
mnemonic: CARICATURE → you CARRY a feature to an extreme → an exaggerated drawing.

core_meaning: to grasp mentally; to understand; to include or comprise
figurative_meaning: to encompass
etymology_root: From Latin comprehendere 'seize, comprise', from com- 'together' + prehendere 'grasp'.

by_level.simple: I cannot comprehend why he did that.
by_level.intermediate: The course aims to help students comprehend complex scientific concepts.
by_level.advanced: The true magnitude of the tragedy is difficult to comprehend.

formal: It is essential to comprehend the legal implications of this document.
The study comprehends all aspects of the phenomenon.
informal: Do you comprehend what I'm saying?
I just can't comprehend his behavior.
technical: In reading theory, comprehension involves extracting and constructing meaning from text.
The term 'set' in mathematics comprehends all its elements.
literary: A love so vast it comprehended all creation.
He could not comprehend the darkness that had settled in her heart.

grammar_usage_notes: More formal than 'understand'. The 'include' meaning is now rare.
exceptions_restrictions: Often used for understanding complex or large-scale things.
mnemonic: COMPREHEND → to get a hold of (HEND) the meaning completely (COM-) → to understand.

core_meaning: the possibility or likelihood of some future event occurring; a person regarded as likely to succeed or as a potential customer; to search for mineral deposits
figurative_meaning: a wide view
etymology_root: From Latin prospectus 'distant view, outlook', from prospicere 'look forward', from pro- 'forward' + specere 'to look'.

by_level.simple: The prospect of a holiday made everyone happy.
by_level.intermediate: He is a leading prospect for the job.
by_level.advanced: The company is prospecting for oil in the Arctic.

formal: There is little prospect of the bill being passed.
The economic prospects for the coming year are favorable.
informal: I'm not relishing the prospect of telling him.
He's a hot prospect for the baseball team.
technical: In mining, a prospecting license grants the right to search for minerals.
In sales, a prospect is a potential customer who has been qualified as likely to buy.
literary: The prospect from the hill was breathtaking.
The bleak prospect of a future without him stretched before her.

grammar_usage_notes: As a noun, often used with 'of' (prospect of something). As a verb, it is intransitive (prospect for gold).
exceptions_restrictions: The meaning changes significantly based on context (future possibility vs. searching for minerals).
mnemonic: PROSPECT → looking FORWARD (pro-) to what you expect to see → a future possibility.

core_meaning: having or showing a modest or low estimate of one's own importance; to lower in dignity or importance
figurative_meaning: of low social or economic rank
etymology_root: From Old French umble, from Latin humilis 'low, lowly', from humus 'ground'.

by_level.simple: Despite his fame, he remained a humble person.
by_level.intermediate: She came from a humble background.
by_level.advanced: The champion was humbled by the young newcomer in a stunning defeat.

formal: He accepted the award with a humble demeanor.
The experience served to humble his pride.
informal: My humble abode is your humble abode.
I had to eat humble pie and admit I was wrong.
literary: In my humble opinion, she is the finest writer of her generation.
The mighty oak grew from a humble acorn.

grammar_usage_notes: As an adjective, it is a positive character trait. As a verb, it can be negative (to humiliate) or positive (to make someone less arrogant).
exceptions_restrictions: Can be positive (modest) or negative (lowly, humiliated) depending on context.
mnemonic: HUMBLE → from HUMus (earth) → close to the ground, not proud.

core_meaning: an earnest or humble request
figurative_meaning: a supplication
etymology_root: From Old French entraitier, based on Latin tractare 'to handle'.

by_level.simple: She ignored his entreaties to stay.
by_level.intermediate: The prisoner's entreaty for mercy fell on deaf ears.
by_level.advanced: All their entreaties could not sway the king from his purpose.

formal: I must make an earnest entreaty for your reconsideration.
His final entreaty was for the well-being of his children.
informal: Stop your entreaties; my answer is no.
It was more of an entreaty than a request.
literary: Her eyes held a silent entreaty.
He listened to the entreaties of the people, his heart moved by their plight.

grammar_usage_notes: A formal word for a serious and humble request.
exceptions_restrictions: More formal and urgent than 'request'.
mnemonic: ENTREATY → a serious and earnest REQUEST.

core_meaning: a person's inherent qualities of mind and character; the way in which something is placed or arranged; the power to deal with something as one pleases
figurative_meaning: the final settlement of a matter
etymology_root: From Latin disposito(n-), from disponere 'arrange' (from dis- 'apart' + ponere 'to place').

by_level.simple: She has a cheerful disposition.
by_level.intermediate: The general ordered the disposition of troops along the border.
by_level.advanced: The judge has sole disposition over the case.

formal: His nervous disposition made him unsuitable for high-pressure work.
The will provided for the disposition of the estate.
informal: He's got a mean disposition.
The car is at your disposition for the weekend.
technical: In psychology, dispositional factors are internal personality traits, as opposed to situational factors.
In law, the disposition of a case is its final settlement by the court.
literary: A melancholy disposition colored all his perceptions.
By a fortunate disposition of fate, they met again.

grammar_usage_notes: Has several distinct meanings based on context: personality, arrangement, or control.
exceptions_restrictions: A versatile word used in many fields.
mnemonic: DISPOSITION → your natural tendency to DISPOSE yourself to act in a certain way → your temperament.

core_meaning: something that causes pain or suffering
literal_meaning: a state of pain or distress
figurative_meaning: a cause of great suffering
etymology_root: From Old French afliccion, from Latin afflictio(n-), from affligere 'knock down, weaken'.

by_level.simple: Blindness is a terrible affliction.
by_level.intermediate: He bore his affliction with great courage.
by_level.advanced: The country has endured the twin afflictions of war and famine.

formal: The community rallied to support those suffering from this affliction.
He viewed his poverty not as an affliction, but as a test of character.
informal: This headache is a real affliction.
He's got some kind of skin affliction.
technical: In medical contexts, an affliction is a disease or ailment.
The study focused on the psychological impact of chronic affliction.
literary: She endured her afflictions with a saintly patience.
Love is the only balm for the affliction of a lonely heart.

grammar_usage_notes: A formal word for a serious cause of suffering, often one that is ongoing.
exceptions_restrictions: Often used for serious, long-term suffering.
mnemonic: AFFLICTION → something that AFFLICTs you → causes pain and suffering.
